pullRequest.body:
when everything is affine independent. Also a related affine span lemma.

From LeanCamCombi


---

nodes.body:
Thanks for these results btw, they're very desirable!

bors d+

:v: YaelDillies can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7544873718/job/20539212917)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7544873718/job/20539213148)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7544873718/job/20539212103)

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (hs : AffineIndependent k ((↑) : s → V)) ```

Can you add a docstring explaining how this is different?
```suggestion
/-- This is a version of `Finset.mem_convexHull` stated without `Finset.centerMass`. -/
lemma Finset.mem_convexHull' {s : Finset E} {x : E} :
```
or similar
`hs` seems like a rather strong assumption; the lemma is still true for `t₁ = {(0, 0), (0, 1), (0, 2)}` and `t₂ = {(0, 0), (1, 0), (2, 0)}`, right?

It is in general very wrong. Consider the intersection of two random triangles in the plane: it might be an hexagon!

This condition is the gluing condition in the definition of `Geometry.SimplicialComplex`. You can't expect it to be true in much greater generality than what I have here.
I think `hs` is sufficiently weird here that a docstring is justified, and maybe a longer lemma name (`convexHull_inter_of_subset`?)
It's in the `AffineIndependent` namespace! I thought this would be enough to disambiguate.

Given the docstring, why not
```suggestion
/-- Two simplices glue nicely if the union of their vertices is affine independent. -/
lemma AffineIndependent.convexHull_inter (hs : AffineIndependent R ((↑) : (t₁ ∪ t₂) → E)) :
```
There should be some `mono` lemma that lets you recover your lemma via `union_subset`, right?

This is a much less practical statement. Going from mine to yours is using `subset_union_left` + `subset_union_right` (discoverable) while going from yours to mine involves using `AffineIndependent.comp_embedding` + `Set.inclusion` + `Set.inclusion_injective` + `union_subset` (not very discoverable).

The translation from yours to mine would be simpler if we had an abbreviation for `AffineIndependent R ((↑) : s → E)`, but that feels out of scope for this PR.
In that case, can we have both, with a comment on my one stating that often yours is easier to use?

```suggestion
  simpa using finrank_le.trans <| finrank_vectorSpan_range_add_one_le _ _
```

"smaller" to me implies `<`; can you clarify here?

Is the strict inequality true as well, with a strong `hst`?
I've added the strict inequality

```suggestion
/-- Two simplices glue nicely if the intersection of their vertices is affine independent. -/
```
No, I do mean union here.
Oops yes, I get it now sorry.

```suggestion
    (hst : affineSpan k (s : Set V) < affineSpan k (t : Set V)) : s.card < t.card := by
```

I'm not sure about this syntax. How about the GOFS:
```suggestion
  have ht : ∀ x, x ∈ t₁ → x ∉ t₂ → w₁ x = 0 := fun x hx₁ hx₂ ↦ by
```

I quite like the new syntax actually. Think about how you would write this as a lemma. Would you rather write
```
lemma ht (x) (hx₁ : x ∈ t₁) (hx₂ : x ∉ t₂) : w₁ x = 0 := by
```
or
```
lemma ht : ∀ x, x ∈ t₁ → x ∉ t₂ → w₁ x = 0 := fun x hx₁ hx₂ ↦ by
```

I am aware of the analogy to the way we inline hypotheses when stating lemmas and I might be guilty of just not being sufficiently used to this yet.

This is subjective so I don't insist.

I find this much easier to parse:
```suggestion
  let w : E → R := fun x ↦ (if x ∈ t₁ then w₁ x else 0) - if x ∈ t₂ then w₂ x else 0
```
As above, take it or leave it.

What about
```suggestion
  let w (x : E) : R := (if x ∈ t₁ then w₁ x else 0) - if x ∈ t₂ then w₂ x else 0
```
Is that parseable enough to you?
Sure!
What about `let w (x : E) : R :=`?
How is that different to what I suggested?
Eric's remark looks identical to me too: I suspect he wrote his remark into an unrefreshed comment box.

It's a bit evil to have this `erw`. I believe it is due to the syntactic difference between `{x // x ∈ (s : Set V)}` and `{x // x ∈ (s : Finset V)}`. E.g., this works:
```lean
  have foo : finrank k (vectorSpan k (Set.range <| ((↑) : { x // x ∈ (s : Set V) } → V))) + 1 = _ :=
  hs.finrank_vectorSpan_add_one
  rw [foo] at finrank_le
```
Is there an easy way to sidestep this grossness?

Yes indeed I used `erw` because of the difference between `{x // x ∈ (s : Set V)}` and `{x // x ∈ (s : Finset V)}`. Why do you think `erw` needs eradicating? It was designed for situations like this one.

The thing I don't like about `erw` is that can be abused and it's impossible to tell why it is needed in any given instance so I usually factor it out.

I do however agree that this is reasonable use. If you wish to keep it I suggest adding a comment along the lines of:
```
-- We use `erw` to elide the difference between `{x // x ∈ (s : Set V)}` and `{x // x ∈ (s : Finset V)}`
```
and likewise at the other use below

```suggestion
  -- We use `erw` to elide the difference between `↥s` and `↥(s : Set V)}`
  erw [hs.finrank_vectorSpan_add_one] at finrank_le
```

```suggestion
  -- We use `erw` to elide the difference between `↥s` and `↥(s : Set V)}`
  erw [hs.finrank_vectorSpan_add_one] at finrank_lt
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: Intersection of convex hulls is convex hull of intersection
